title: The two opposing views of October 7 and its aftermath
summary: Depending on whether you see the terrorist massacre as an episode in a conflict that has been going on since 1948 or as the start of a new era that abolishes previous parameters, the perception of the war between Israel and Hamas changes radically.

title: Israel says it struck two military bases in central Syria, including one in Palmyra
summary: Israel says it wants to prevent weapons from falling into the hands of the new authorities it considers jihadists.

title: Hundreds of thousands defy Erdogan to protest Istanbul mayor's arrest
summary: Clashes erupted on the sidelines of the protest, with riot police firing tear gas and rubber bullets, according to two AFP correspondents who were both hit in the leg. Protests spread from Istanbul to at least 40 of Turkey's 81 provinces.

title: 'Trump staged a putsch at the Kennedy Center, and he didn't choose this cultural jewel at random'
summary: Donald Trump is the self-proclaimed president of this federally-owned entertainment complex in Washington. Le Monde columnist Michel Guerrin believes that the venue is ideally suited to a reconquest of identity and patriotism.

title: Kirsty Coventry at the head of the International Olympic Committee, a powerful symbol for world sport
summary: The former Zimbabwean swimmer became the first-ever female IOC president on March 20. This is a break with tradition for the world's supreme sporting body, renowned for its conservatism, and confirms the influence of outgoing president Thomas Bach.

title: Mélanie Joly, the Canadian minister standing up to the Trump administration
summary: In the midst of a trade war between the United States and Canada, the Canadian foreign minister has been the most direct, notably ahead of welcoming her American counterpart, Marco Rubio, on March 12.

title: Israel defense minister threatens to annex parts of Gaza
summary: Hundreds of people, including children, have been killed since Israel broke the ceasefire. The foreign ministers of Germany, France and Britain called for an immediate return to a Gaza ceasefire in a joint statement late Friday, calling the new strikes 'a dramatic step backward.'

title: Under threat from Trump, Columbia University agrees to changes
summary: Earlier this month, the Trump administration pulled $400 million in funding over the university's handling of protests against Israel's military campaign in Gaza. The announcement drew immediate condemnation from faculty and free speech groups.

title: London's Heathrow slowly resumes flights after a fire cut power to Europe's busiest airport
summary: The first plane took off from Heathrow Airport Friday evening after day-long closure sparked by a nearby fire grounded hundreds of flights. Police said that they are not treating this incident as 'suspicious.'

title: Italy's Meloni, caught between the EU and the US, benefits from divisions in the opposition
summary: The Italian prime minister is moderately supportive of Ukraine and European rearmament plans while also expressing her support for the Trump administration. In her own country, she must contend with a pacifist movement cutting across different parties, including her own coalition.

title: Niger declares 3 days of mourning after 44 people were killed inattack
summary: The attack occurred early in the afternoon as people were attending a prayer service at the mosque, the ministry statement said. Another 13 people were wounded.

title: French IS jihadist who held journalists in Syria gets life sentence: 'I will never apologize'
summary: Mehdi Nemmouche, 39, is charged with holding four journalists captive more than a decade ago in Syria. He is already in prison after a Belgian court sentenced him to life in prison in 2019 for killing four people at a Jewish museum in May 2014.

title: In the heart of Paris, Merci's second store is an open secret
summary: Following its first successful boutique that opened in 2009, the concept store has opened a second space, in a former 1950s post office. Featuring two separate entrances, this open-plan store cultivates an aesthetic that is both industrial and artisanal.

title: French museum uncovers in storage picture by Renaissance woman master
summary: The painting, 'Portrait of a Gentleman, his Daughter and a Servant,' is now attributed to Lavinia Fontana, one of the very first women to make a career out of painting in Western art. It will now be a centerpiece of the collection of the Musée de la Chartreuse in Douai.

title: Cartoonist accuses French Education Ministry of censorship for canceling his 'Beauty and the Beast'
summary: A comic book version of the 18th-century tale was supposed to be gifted to all children entering middle school this summer. But at the last minute, officials canceled its printing. Cartoonist Jul compared the move to 'Trump and his administration.'

title: Trump's return is pushing India and the EU closer together
summary: Despite differing positions on Russia, Brussels and New Delhi have resumed negotiations on a trade agreement that was suspended in 2013.

title: Macron announces new Ukraine 'coalition' summit in Paris on March 27
summary: The French President, together with British Prime Minister Keir Starmer, has been leading efforts to form a coalition in support of Ukraine since US President Donald Trump opened direct negotiations with Russia last month.

title: Rearming Europe: Brussels grapples with prospect of new large-scale loan
summary: Ahead of Friedrich Merz's arrival in power in Berlin, several leaders are pushing for Eurobonds to fund the continent's defense. The European People's Party, the leading political force within the European institutions, is in favor 'if necessary.'

title: 'The Alto Knights,' a decrepit Mafia duel between De Niro and himself
summary: Barry Levinson stages a confrontation between two crime bosses, played by the actor, who delivers a double, laborious performance.

title: In Peru, culture is under censorship
summary: Movies, plays, exhibitions, festivals are being canceled. The reactionary and conservative right wing is increasingly pressuring artists.

title: Heavyweight boxing champion George Foreman dies at 76
summary: Foreman, who fought and lost against Muhammad Ali in boxing's iconic 1974 'Rumble in the Jungle' before reclaiming the title two decades later, died on Friday, his family announced in a statement.

title: Bird flu:  US Health Secretary Robert F. Kennedy Jr. dismays scientists by suggesting to let the virus run
summary: The idea, taken up by the Secretary of State for Agriculture, Brooke Rollins, worries scientists and veterinarians alike. It would give the virus the opportunity to mutate and become more dangerous.

title: Paris exhibit highlights artists' fascination with the end of the world
summary: 'Apocalypse: Yesterday and Tomorrow,' at the Bibliothèque Nationale de France, brings together some 300 works from the 9th century to the present day, inspired by the text on the end of the world by John of Patmos.

title: Getting outdoors, mixing work and pleasure and cheaper trips: How Covid (partly) changed tourism in France
summary: While the sector has been on a roller-coaster ride over the past five years, it hasn't really switched course since the pandemic. However, new types of behaviors linked to a yearning for nature, inflation and the rise of remote work have taken hold.

title: Israel: Power struggle between government and judiciary thrusts the country into the unknown
summary: Benjamin Netanyahu's cabinet voted unanimously on Friday to dismiss Ronen Bar, head of Israel's domestic intelligence service. The Supreme Court suspended the legally dubious procedure, and their decision was supported by the Attorney General. The prime minister has decided to force the issue.

title: How a French researcher being refused entry to the US turned into a diplomatic mess
summary: The US administration stated that the scientist had sensitive data on his computer and phone, contradicting the version of events put forward by the French research minister, who had publicized the incident.

title: Five activities around Paris to get teens to finally put down their phones
summary: It's not always easy to get young people out of bed. From skateboarding to cinema, street art and fashion, here's our selection of outings and workshops designed just for them, in the Paris region. Just the thing to (temporarily) combat laziness.

title: US: Trump administration revokes legal migrant status for 500,000 people
summary: These people had lawfully come to the US under a Joe Biden-era program for Cubans, Haitians, Nicaraguans, and Venezuelans. They will lose legal protections 30 days after the order is published, amid the Trump administration's mass deportation campaign.

title: Pope Francis is due to make first public appearance on Sunday
summary: After a stretch in the Agostino Gemelli hospital due to pneumonia in both lungs, the longest hospitalization of his papacy, Pope Francis is due to wave and offer a blessing from the hospital after Angelus prayers on Sunday.

title: IS jailers trial: The anti-Western, pro-Russian rhetoric of Mehdi Nemmouche, sentenced to life in prison
summary: A few hours before the verdict was delivered on Friday, defendant Mehdi Nemmouche, who claimed to be a 'terrorist,' seized on the platform the trial represented to launch into a violent anti-Western diatribe, inspired by jihadist and Kremlin propaganda.

title: Turkey: Istanbul Mayor Ekrem Imamoglu's arrest marks the start of a new authoritarian era
summary: By arresting his main political opponent, Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan is transforming his regime into a true autocracy. Major demonstrations have taken place in many cities across the country.

title: Heathrow Airport back to 'fully operational' after fire
summary: Flights began landing at Europe's biggest airport around 7 pm on Friday night, after a fire on Thursday night had knocked out power at the London airport, leading to thousands of delays and a backlog of flights to clear.

title: 'This terrifying face is the true face of war': A new lease on life for Ukraine's 'broken faces'
summary: Soldiers and civilians left disfigured, and then stigmatized, by the ravages of war, are being treated, free of charge, by the Unburned program, run by 33 clinics across the country.

title: Tens of thousands took to the streets in France against racism and far-right
summary: Some protesters, in Paris and cities across the country, took aim at the US administration and others carrying Palestinian flags.

title: At least 8 killed in Israeli strikes on Lebanon after rocket fire
summary: Israeli PM Benjamin Netanyahu and Defense Minister Israel Katz ordered 'a second wave of strikes against dozens of Hezbollah targets in Lebanon,' in response to a rocket attack, the defense ministry said.  Hezbollah denied any involvement.

title: The Salève cable car, vertiginous architecture
summary: A balcony suspended above the landscape, a restaurant opening up onto wide-open spaces, a panoramic terrace: The project, by Devaux & Devaux Architects, in France's Alpine southeast offers visitors an intense sensory experience.
